reviews.review_text: My thoughts on Trine:  Trine is a beautifully designed 2D action-jumping-fighting-puzzle solving indie game. You get to play three differennt characters at once - a knight, a thief and a wizard. While obviously only controlling one of them at a time, you can switch between those three at any time, using their individual strenghts and abilities to make it to the other side of the map. As the knight, you're armed with shield and sword and are capable of lifting heavy objects and throw them at your enemies. The shield can be used to block any incoming attack, while the sword is the perfect weapon to deal with the growing numbers of skeletons, bats, and other enemies that you'll encounter. The thief is armed with a bow and thus able to fight enemies from afar (duh), and can shoot a rope on wooden objects to swing across pits, pull herself out of them in case you still manage to fall and perform cool looking jumps. As the wizard, you can summon cubes or planks to make yourself an easy way across pits, build stairs to get over high cliffs or drop them on your enemies.  Each ability and spell can be upgraded throughout the game, like letting you shoot several arrows at once, create more cubes to stack on each other or make your sword even deadlier. There are hundrets of casks granting you exp or mana hidden across the game and finding (and reaching!) them all is no easy task!  The graphics are among the best I've seen on a 2D game, only behind this games successor Trine 2. A special praise goes to the awesome person who created this beautiful soundtrack, the music fits this game just perfectly.   I personally didn't like all of the jumping parts that much, just because I'm usually not a big fan of jumping games (and suck at it too), and died several times over. I know I'm criticising a jumping game for its jumping parts, so someone who's into that kind of stuff will have a really good and challenging time with this game. For people like myself, it's still enjoyable, and swining around with the thief is fun, but after a while it can get boring. There could be more different enemies too, since in like the first three chapters or so all you fight are skeletons and bats.   Lots of good things to be said and a few bad too, still I'd recommend anyone to buy this game, especially if it's on sale for like € 1,- or so.

I wish there were fewer of them. They usually do not pose any threat and you just have to stand and shoot them, one by one, one by one, hordes of skeletons on every level section. This review is for the game ''Trine'',a side-scrolling action platform and puzzle video game,developed by the video game company ''Frozenbyte'' and published by Nobilis(wordwide).It was released in July 3,2009 for Microsoft Windows and since then the game has been released for the PlayStation Network,Mac OS X and for Linux as well.Trine uses the Proprietary engine.  Plot Trine takes place in a magical but destroyed kingdom.After a brief period of peace,the king died without leaving any heir.So the kingdom descented to anarchy.During this political instability an undead army appears and attacks the kingdom destroying everything that's on its path.  After some time three heroes,unkown to each other,reach the Astral Academy,a magical institution,where they touch a magical object,later said to be the Trine,and their souls bind together.After that incident they search for a way to free themselves of that peculiar effect.The trio must eventually undergoe an adventure searching for three artifacts that once reunited they could be free.Apparently the Trine is the artifact of souls and without it the other two(the artifact of the body and the artifact of the mind) created the undead making them responsible for all the chaos that polutes the kingdom.  After finding them they face a last ultimate challenge where they combine the Trine with the two lost artifacts,unbinding their souls forever.The game ends with the storyteller informing us that the kingdom has been cleansed from the undead and the three proclaiming it as its heroes.  Characters You take control of Zoya,the thief,Amadeus,the wizard,and Pontius,the knight.Each of them has special abilities.Zoya is the stealthy one of the group and uses her bow and arrow,making her an exceptional marksman.Amadeus uses the power of magic,allowing him to conjur objects(planks,cubes,pyramids) helping the team to overcome obstacles and reach remote areas with great ease.Last but not least Pontius uses his sword,shield and sledgehammer with great force,making him the group's main damage dealer.The player is supposed to combine the group's power together in order to accomplish difficult stunts and unlock the group's true prowess.  Recap Incredible game,breathtaking graphics,with exceptional yet simple plot.Enjoyed every bit of it and i definetely recommend it.  Edit Friday 4 July 2014 Trines has been updated with extremely good looking visual customizations and now is called Trine the Enchanted edition.You should try it out,everybody can be a Beta participant thanks to Frozenbyte developers.  P.S Support the developers.Frozenbyte thank you for this game.

Trine is a game I can't recommend enough. It's a physics platformer with a rather unique mechanic of 3 playable characters. They are tied together by magic so you can switch between them at any time and use their abilities to make your way through the levels. Puzzles are quite varied requiring a number of different strategies, especially if you want to collect all the experience orbs which can be quite difficult to reach. All of the characters are well-balanced and necessary to proceed through the game. The game is also very well-written and acted which is a welcome change from most platformers.  Where Trine really shines though is the graphics. The art in this game is absolutely stunning and it's amazing how well it runs even on older hardware. It also makes use of nVidia PhysX for high quality physics simulation (nVidia hardware not required.) The world and levels are very well designed and quite engrossing as well.  The only thing this game is missing is coop, but that was added for the sequel which is just as awesome. Play them both! You won't regret it.

First of all, buy this game!  I am not really a fan of platformers and puzzle games but I really loved this one. And there are dozens of reasons I did.  Gameplay: It feels like an old school platformer with all the running and jumping across the screen, but it gives you something more than that. Unique abilities of the heroes allows you to make your own choices of how you want to cross a gap or how you want to get to some extra experience points. Moreover, you can vary methods of getting rid off your enemies - making it shooting an arrow (thief), waving your sword (knight) or smashing them with a box (wizard). The puzzles player encounter through the game are not hard at all, still hard enough to feel satisfaction of getting through from time to time. Maybe that doesn't sound that fun or new, but believe me this is really entertaining.   The only down thing about the gameplay is Boss fights that feel repetitive and rather dumb - hit & jump.  Gaphics: The game has unique atmosphere and the art of each level is just beautiful. I found myself feeling really enjoying the picture. Enchanted Edition stands for enhanced graphics edition for the original game and it feels pretty up-to-date.  Controls: Strange thing - I tried to play the game using Xbox controller and found mouse and keyboard far better way of playing the game. Still it is pretty much playable using gamepad. I was also happy to find out that there is a local co-op mode in the game which allows you to play the game with your friends using gamepads and mouse & keyboard at one machine.  Verdict: This game has a really strong impression on me. I was surprised how I got into it easily and spent first two hours feeling like it was only 15 minutes. I really like spending some time after work playing it - feels relaxing. And after I finish this one there are still Trine 2 and 3 that await me.  I recommend it to all of you guys.

Quick Summary: Side scrolling platformer with great graphics and some tricky (but not too tricky) puzzle solving and light combat. Great game for casual co-op as well.  You play a trio of heroes trapped in a single body by a mysterious magical artifact called the Trine. While your souls are bound, you can be any one of the three characters at any time: Wizard, Thief, or Knight. Your quest is to find out why you’re bound together and how to undo the “curse.”   The game is played with keyboard and mouse though other players can drop in using a game controller on the same computer. You progress mostly from left to right in a two dimensional plane with a lot of jumping and scrambling from one level to another. With a press of a button you can instantly switch between the three characters, each with their unique skills useful for fighting (knight) grappling (thief) or conjuring objects to use (wizard). Each of the characters has their own life bar so if they die you need to either make do with the other 2 characters or backtrack until you get to a checkpoint (a glowing sphere). You can backtrack as much as you want in this game, which is useful since there are a lot of collectibles to be found. The collectibles mainly come in the form of experience potions, and when you level up you can upgrade skills unique to each character class (for example increasing the number of objects the wizard can have conjured at any one time).  Pros: +Amazing graphics for a little indie game. The environments look 3D despite being a simple side scroller. +Free upgrade to the Enchanted Edition. The upgraded version uses the Trine 2 engine and got a large number of new Steam achievements. +Nice story with good narration. The narrator appears as an announcer in Dota 2 so you may recognize his voice.  Cons: Not much really, the game is awesome.  This is a great, cheap game that anyone can get into. If you didn’t get it for free sometime in the past you can probably see it in Humble Bundles occasionally. Play with friends and family!

Verdict: Why haven't you bought this already?!  This game has just had a completely free, absolutely stunning graphics upgrade, and co-op multi-player added where it originally had none, 5 years after original release, FOR FREE. Let this sink in for a moment, in this day and age of nickle&diming for worthless trinket pixel additions or triple A pricing for practically untouched re-releases. If you already own this, it is worth reinstalling and playing all over again; if you don't own it, it's worth every penny.  At the current sales price of 80-90% off for ALL Frozenbytes games (Trine 1&2 and Shadowgrounds), you really should just stop reading this and go buy whatever parts your collection is missing, right now. In fact, buy copies for all your friends. This company needs encouragement, and their success needs to be a bright beacon of enlightenment for games developers and publishers out there.  There's free demos to all their games if you're still doubting. Its unique experience is best understood through direct gameplay anyway. Get it, play it, then tell me again this isn't worth paying for.  Btw, performance tip: if you use the enchanted version with an NVidia GPU, make sure to add the trine1_32bit.exe file to the NVidia control panel under Manage 3D Settings, otherwise even though it uses the same engine as Trine 2, you will get a lot worse performance. Steam says I've played this game for only a few minutes, but I played it mostly online due to some internet troubles. Trine is a side-scroller that requires you to switch between three different characters, each with their own abilities, in order to solve puzzles and fight creatures. There's a lot of exploration involved and a lot of secrets to uncover, made up of experience (used to upgrade your characters' abilities) and treasure chests (which hold items which also expand upon your characters' abilities).  The gameplay is fun. Each of the characters brings something unique and interesting to the gameplay. The thief can shoot arrows and uses a grappling hook to get around and up to higher places. The wizard can create boxes and planks to help move machinery and reach high places, as well as move objects around using telekinises type power. And the knight has a shield for blocking attacks and projectiles, as well as a sword for attacking enemies. These obviously expand and get upgraded as you find experience and secrets, but I won't spoil it by explaining how.  You will get the most fun out of the game by switching between the characters regularly and using their strengths based on the situation (either in a combined or singular way).  The game itself is absolutely beautiful. Even on the absolutely lowest graphic specs, it's beautiful to look at, and one of the main draws to the game. The story is surprisingly interesting. It's not amazingly detailed or deep, but it's told well through narration in between and during levels. The narration and character voices are sort of over the top on purpose, kind of like in a fairtytale way. The levels themselves are also varied and each has a unique look. And the music fits each level perfectly.  It's a not a super long game (I'd say reaching the end would take somewhere between 5 and 10 hours on average), but it seemed like a good length. There is some replayability in finding secrets that you missed in each level as well as a range of difficulties. I played it on medium which was fairly easy, although enjoyable nonetheless.  I'm looking forward to playing Trine 2 as well as 3 eventually.

It takes about 10 hours to complete, but there is lots of fun in going back to complete Steam achievements. I'm running it on Windows 7 (64-bit) with no issues. Get it on sale for a few bucks, and you won't be disappointed. I'm about to purchase the Trinelogy!

Clearly a game intended to be more of a visual and audio based experience than actual gameplay. Very standard platformer that focuses on using 3 different characters. First is a wizard that creates boxes and bridges to help cross most gaps. Second is a thief with a bow and ability to swing between places if you can grapple onto wood. Lastly there is the knight who is your shield and sword.  Most of the game you will find yourself using the wizard as he can do 95% of stuff. Kill/defend with summoned items, or make accessing spots easier. There is no real challenge puzzle wise except the last 2-3 levels and possibly locating where the last experiance flask is in the level.  The levels themselves typically have a enchanted forest feeling, with a few castle levels. They don't feel too different from eachother which makes it a bit boring. The game is partially fun but missing immersion, nothing really draws you in gameplay wise. Not really any bosses, no variation on enemies past shield/arrow/pyro, just keep running while summoning some platforms and collect green flasks.  The graphics and music make for a nice single playthrough once and the main reason I hit recommend, but I would only get it when on sale. If you are specifically looking for platformer games, I would stick with the classics like Mario/Donkey Kong, they are more challenging, longer gameplay and more fun.  Personal experience score: 5.5/10  Story: 3/10 - Your really basic medieval story, not really a story based game in my view  Sound: 10/10 - Nice soundtrack  Graphics: 10/10 - Very nice art style  Controls: 9/10 - Easy to use and very basic, the hardest part is jumping to the right points  Game Length: 2/10 - 4 hours only with getting most experience flasks (a few short on each level only from achievements)
